comment._content: Indicator Takes Meadow Brook Cup.Stirring Race for Hunt Trophy on Harry Payne Whitney's Estate at Wheatley Hills. Harry Payne Whitney played the part of an English country squire to perfection at his country place at Wheatley Hills yesterday, the occasion being the annual meeting of the Meadow Brook Steeplechase Association. For the farmers and their families in the vicinity Mr. Whitney provided an abundant lunch, and incidentally an opportunity to get enough out of "them city fellers" to buy all the fertilizers they will need for the coming year. Source: New York Times on May 10, 1914 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10E14F7355D1373... comment.author: 33593953@N02
comment._content: Thanks, all, for the likely place and date of the photo, and clues about the identities of the people. From checking our Biographical File of pictures in the reading room, it appears that this is Harry Payne Whitney (left) with his hand on the shoulder of Robert Bacon (1860-1919), who was briefly Secretary of State in 1909, then Ambassador to France until 1912. We have other photographs of Robert Bacon in the Bain Collection. Here's one that appears in our Biographical File with a news article copied on the back about his departure from the ambassador's post: hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.20701 . The young woman is apparently Robert Bacon's daughter-in-law, Virginia Murray Bacon, married to his son, Robert Low Bacon (1884-1938) who became a Congressman from New York (seen in this photographic print, also from the Bain Collection: hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/cph.3a42131 - one for which we apparently do not have an original negative). We'll add some identifying information when we update the record.
